course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: Why restate the problem in your own words?
options: If you cannot restate it clearly, you do not own it
To use more jargon and sound expert
To please others who prefer complexity
It is optional when time is limited

questions.question: What is a good test for whether you own the problem?
options: You can explain it to someone else in 30 seconds without jargon
You have a long document describing it
You have consensus from the team
You have a budget approved for it

questions.question: What should you do with the restatement once it is clear?
options: Lock it as the working problem you will solve
Forget it and move to solutions
Add more jargon for precision
Delegate it only and do not use it

questions.question: A problem is stated in technical jargon. What is the next step?
options: Rewrite it in plain language so anyone could understand
Keep the jargon for accuracy
Shorten it only without changing words
Skip restatement and start solving

questions.question: What is the risk of skipping restatement and going straight to solutions?
options: Solving the wrong problem or a fuzzy one
Faster delivery with no downside
No significant risk in most cases
Better ideas from jumping to solutions

questions.question: Which is a restatement that shows ownership?
options: A one-sentence gap between current and desired state in plain language
A copy of the original brief unchanged
A list of symptoms only without a gap
A solution disguised as a problem statement

questions.question: Why avoid jargon in the restatement?
options: Jargon often hides fuzzy thinking; plain language forces clarity
Jargon is always wrong in business
Plain language is shorter and faster
There is no strong reason to avoid it
